Problem:
Consider a function representing a complex variable transformation given by \\( f(z) = e^{i\\omega t}z \\), where \\( \\omega \\) is a constant representing angular frequency, and z is a complex variable. We are considering the evolution of this transformation over time t and its impact when combined with an integral transformation defined by \\( G(z) = \\int_{-\\infty}^\\infty e^{-st}z(t) dt \\), where s is a complex parameter.

If the transformation \\( f(z) \\) is applied to an initial complex number \\( z_0 \\) at t = 0 and then evolves over time according to the integral transformation \\( G(z) \\) without further mathematical manipulation, will \\( G(z(t)) \\) at t = T have the same phase as if \\( z_0 \\) was processed directly by \\( G(z) \\) at t = T?
Explanation: The transformation \\( f(z) = e^{i\\omega t}z \\) essentially rotates the complex number z in the complex plane over time, changing its phase but not its magnitude. Given that \\( G(z) \\) integrates across time, integrating a rotationally altered complex number will accumulate changes in phase, resulting in a different effect compared to a direct application of \\( G(z) \\) on the untransformed initial value.
